For that reason, we are not able to offer you admission this round. If later rounds make it clear that no higher-priority candidates will be pursuing School_E and the seat remains available, we will reassess at that time.

1) Would you consider admitting me once you have received [APPLY] decisions from Students A–D (even if they have not applied to School_E), or
2) Is there a particular later round or stage when you stop holding the seat absent an actual [APPLY] from a higher-priority student?

If you can share the criterion you will use, I will submit an [APPLY] immediately as soon as that condition is satisfied.

Sincerely,

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your continued interest and for asking for a clear criterion.

Because our process is priority-based and an [ACCEPT] creates a binding match that removes us from further rounds, the key condition for us to extend an offer to a lower-priority applicant is that we have sufficient confidence that no higher-priority candidate (Students A–D) will be seeking School_E.

In practical terms:
- We cannot use other schools’ outcomes (e.g., whether A–D have applied elsewhere) as a formal trigger, and we cannot rely on or disclose other students’ status.
- We also cannot commit to a specific round cutoff in advance.
- The only definitive trigger is the late stage of the process when it becomes clear that no higher-priority student is going to submit an [APPLY] to School_E before the market ends.

If you remain interested, the best way to keep yourself eligible is to continue checking in and submitting an [APPLY] in later rounds; if we reach a point where we determine the seat would otherwise go unused and no higher-priority applicant is pursuing us, we will reassess at that time.

Sincerely,
School_E Admissions

[TALK]
